articles.headline: Philippine Leader Shifts Drug War to Officials, Meeting Resistance and Approval
articles.snippet: In what seemed to be a new phase of the effort, President Rodrigo Duterte took on judges and police generals, military officials and mayors, among others.
articles.abstract: In what seemed to be a new phase of the effort, President Rodrigo Duterte took on judges and police generals, military officials and mayors, among others.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANILA — Samsudin Dimaukom, the mayor of a town in the southern Philippines, was watching television last Sunday after midnight when he was startled to hear the country’s new president call out his name.

articles.headline: Fox News Names 2 Insiders to Top Posts
articles.snippet: Bill Shine and Jack Abernethy, veterans of the organization, were named by Rupert Murdoch to help fill the void left by the ouster of Roger Ailes.
articles.abstract: Bill Shine and Jack Abernethy, veterans of the organization, were named by Rupert Murdoch to help fill the void left by the ouster of Roger Ailes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In assuming the leadership of Fox News last month, Rupert Murdoch pledged a fresh start at a network reeling from accusations that its longtime chairman, Roger Ailes, had overseen a culture of harassment and intimidation.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Cost, Not Choice, Is Top Concern of Health Insurance Customers
articles.snippet: Millions of people looking for insurance in the federal marketplaces are more concerned with cost than with finding a favorite doctor or trusted company.
articles.abstract: Millions of people looking for insurance in the federal marketplaces are more concerned with cost than with finding a favorite doctor or trusted company.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is all about the price.

articles.headline: A Simple Test to Dispel the Illusion Behind Stock Buybacks
articles.snippet: Comparing a company’s growth in earnings per share, which can be raised by buying back stock, with its net profit growth can paint a more accurate picture of performance over time.
articles.abstract: Comparing a company’s growth in earnings per share, which can be raised by buying back stock, with its net profit growth can paint a more accurate picture of performance over time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock investors have had one sweet summer so far watching the markets edge higher. With the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index at record highs and nearing 2,200, what’s not to like?

articles.headline: Why Some Life Insurance Premiums Are Skyrocketing
articles.snippet: Insurance companies are facing the problem of selling products in an era of near-zero interest rates, and they’re squeezing many policyholders.
articles.abstract: Insurance companies are facing the problem of selling products in an era of near-zero interest rates, and they’re squeezing many policyholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like clockwork, Sara and James Cook paid $452 a month for life insurance. That is, until a letter arrived last year telling the elderly Georgia couple the premiums on the policy they’d had for 25 years were rising sharply.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Aid and Attention Dwindling, Migrant Crisis Intensifies in Greece
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of asylum seekers are languishing in camps, with more trickling in, and neither Western and Northern Europe nor Turkey are doing much to help.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of asylum seekers are languishing in camps, with more trickling in, and neither Western and Northern Europe nor Turkey are doing much to help.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEA KAVALA, Greece — As her young children played near heaps of garbage, picking through burned corn cobs and crushed plastic bottles to fashion new toys, Shiraz Madran, a 28-year-old mother of four, turned with tear-rimmed eyes to survey the desolate encampment that has become her home.

articles.headline: Once Skeptical of Executive Power, Obama Has Come to Embrace It
articles.snippet: Mr. Obama will leave the White House as one of the most prolific authors of major regulations in presidential history.
articles.abstract: Mr. Obama will leave the White House as one of the most prolific authors of major regulations in presidential history.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In nearly eight years in office, President Obama has sought to reshape the nation with a sweeping assertion of executive authority and a canon of regulations that have inserted the United States government more deeply into American life.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: How Producing Clean Power Turned Out to Be a Messy Business
articles.snippet: NRG Energy has become a cautionary tale for power producers trying to figure out how to generate more electricity while curbing greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.abstract: NRG Energy has become a cautionary tale for power producers trying to figure out how to generate more electricity while curbing greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the edge of a bucolic field in Princeton, N.J., an eco-friendly office building recently opened its doors. Plants festoon the roof, a living wall is planned for the lobby, and rainwater storage tanks supply the building’s needs. In the parking lot there are wind turbines, solar panels and electric vehicle charging stations.

articles.headline: Inside the Failing Mission to Tame Donald Trump’s Tongue
articles.snippet: The Republican candidate continues to defy his advisers’ efforts to get him to stick to his message, to the point that they believe he may be beyond coaching.
articles.abstract: The Republican candidate continues to defy his advisers’ efforts to get him to stick to his message, to the point that they believe he may be beyond coaching.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was in a state of shock: He had just fired his campaign manager and was watching the man discuss his dismissal at length on CNN. The rattled candidate’s advisers and family seized the moment for an intervention.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Hard Times in Venezuela Breed Malaria as Desperate Flock to Mines
articles.snippet: Many turn to panning for black-market gold in the watery pits of mines, where mosquitoes infect them. Once they return home to recover, the disease spreads.
articles.abstract: Many turn to panning for black-market gold in the watery pits of mines, where mosquitoes infect them. Once they return home to recover, the disease spreads.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE ALBINO MINE, Venezuela — The 12th time Reinaldo Balocha got malaria, he hardly rested at all. With the fever still rattling his body, he threw a pick ax over his shoulder and got back to work — smashing stones in an illegal gold mine.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Edge in a Donald Trump-Centric Race Has Liberals Wary
articles.snippet: A strategy of courting Republicans and focusing closely on Mr. Trump, they say, may impede Mrs. Clinton’s ability to claim a policy mandate if elected.
articles.abstract: A strategy of courting Republicans and focusing closely on Mr. Trump, they say, may impede Mrs. Clinton’s ability to claim a policy mandate if elected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Liberal Democrats and progressive activists have grown wary of the state of the 2016 presidential race, chafing at Hillary Clinton’s big-tent courtship of Republican leaders they have long opposed and fearing the consequences of shaping the contest as a referendum on Donald J. Trump.

articles.headline: Secret Ledger in Ukraine Lists Cash for Donald Trump’s Campaign Chief
articles.snippet: An examination of the activities of Paul Manafort shows how he benefited from powerful interests that are now under scrutiny.
articles.abstract: An examination of the activities of Paul Manafort shows how he benefited from powerful interests that are now under scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — On a leafy side street off Independence Square in Kiev is an office used for years by Donald J. Trump’s campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, when he consulted for Ukraine’s ruling political party. His furniture and personal items were still there as recently as May.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Mike McIntire and Barry Meier

articles.headline: A Tech Mogul’s Fight to Keep Control of a Newspaper Empire
articles.snippet: Michael W. Ferro Jr., who made himself chairman of Tribune Publishing and changed its name to Tronc, clashed with other investors over Gannett’s takeover bids.
articles.abstract: Michael W. Ferro Jr., who made himself chairman of Tribune Publishing and changed its name to Tronc, clashed with other investors over Gannett’s takeover bids.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early summer, after the company formerly called Tribune Publishing had rejected two takeover offers from Gannett, two of its biggest investors found themselves in an escalating dispute. The investment firm Oaktree Capital Management was publicly questioning the motives of Michael W. Ferro Jr., an investor and the new chairman of the publishing company, in his decision to rebuff Gannett.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Who Might Buy Gawker Media? Here Are Some Possibilities
articles.snippet: As the deadline for bids on the embattled company nears, three to five companies have emerged as the most likely suitors.
articles.abstract: As the deadline for bids on the embattled company nears, three to five companies have emerged as the most likely suitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The end of Gawker Media as an independent company is near.

articles.headline: With N.F.L. Deal, Twitter Live-Streams Its Ambitions
articles.snippet: After the social network streams its first N.F.L. game on Sept. 15, it will assess whether live streaming can be a linchpin of its future.
articles.abstract: After the social network streams its first N.F.L. game on Sept. 15, it will assess whether live streaming can be a linchpin of its future.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last March, Twitter and Facebook, along with other tech companies, faced off over which of them would get the rights to live-stream National Football League games on Thursday nights.

articles.headline: Fox News Turmoil Recalls News Corp. Phone Hacking Scandal
articles.snippet: There were warning signs before a sexual harassment case at Fox News, just as there were before the phone hacking that shook the Murdoch media empire.
articles.abstract: There were warning signs before a sexual harassment case at Fox News, just as there were before the phone hacking that shook the Murdoch media empire.
articles.lead_paragraph: Settlements for alleged inappropriate behavior that continued unabated.

articles.headline: How Millennials Became Spooked by Credit Cards
articles.snippet: Building a credit history holds less appeal for young Americans who had trouble paying off student loans and saw their families’ struggles during the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Building a credit history holds less appeal for young Americans who had trouble paying off student loans and saw their families’ struggles during the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kids these days: They just aren’t pulling out the plastic like they did in the past.

articles.headline: Comedy Central Cancels Larry Wilmore’s Late-Night Show
articles.snippet: The network’s president said that the decision to cancel the show 12 weeks before the presidential election was simple: The show “hasn’t resonated.”
articles.abstract: The network’s president said that the decision to cancel the show 12 weeks before the presidential election was simple: The show “hasn’t resonated.”
articles.lead_paragraph: For almost a decade, the combination of Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert made Comedy Central destination viewing for fans of late-night comedy and barbed political commentary.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Terrorism Plan Mixes Cold War Concepts and Limits on Immigrants
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, in a foreign policy address, called for “extreme vetting” of prospective new arrivals that would include an “ideological test.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, in a foreign policy address, called for “extreme vetting” of prospective new arrivals that would include an “ideological test.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Monday invoked comparisons to the Cold War era in arguing that the United States must wage an unrelenting ideological fight if it is to defeat the Islamic State. He said he would temporarily suspend immigration from “the most dangerous and volatile regions of the world” and judge allies solely on their participation in America’s mission to root out Islamic terrorism.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman
